titleStmt.title: Two letters of great consequence, sent from Hamborough; which were intercepted going to Oxford. The one, to the Lord Digby; the other, to Sir Thomas Rowe; exactly relating the proceedings of the wars between the Swedes and the King of Denmark. In which letters appears the excellent successe of those noble Swedes in their severall defeats against the Danes. Read in the House of Commons this 13. of February, 1643. Ordered by the Commons in Parliament, that these letters be forthwith printed and published: H: Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.
titleStmt.author: Avery, J., 17th cent.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Sweden -- History -- Dano-Swedish Wars, 1643-1660 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: TWO LETTERS Of great Con≈øequence, Sent from HAMBOROVGH; Which were Intercepted going to OXFORD. The one, To the Lord Digby; The other, To Sir Thomas Rowe; Exactly relating the Proceedings of the Wars BETWEEN The Swedes and the King of Denmark. In which Letters appears the excellent Succe≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe Noble SWEDES in their ≈øeverall Defeats again≈øt the DANES. Read in the Hou≈øe of Commons this 13. of February, 1643.

body.p: ORdered by the Commons in Parliament, That the≈øe Letters be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed:

closer.signed: H: El≈øynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.head: To the Right Honourable the Lord DIGBIE, Principall Secretarie of State, and one of the Lords of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt Honourable Privie Councell, &c.

opener.salute: Right Honorable, and my very good Lord,

div.p:
TO clear the doubt and different reports were here ≈øpread of the Duke of Hol≈øteins agreement with Feildmar≈øhall Torten≈øon; (whereof my la≈øt weekes made mention) we have now certaine adverti≈øement that this Prince hath accorded to give one hundred thou≈øand Dollers, to free his own Countrey and people; Ditmar≈øh being exempted, and the Gentry al≈øo within his juri≈ødiction; for the≈øe are to be holden unto a like contribution, and treatment, as the re≈øt of the Gentry of Hol≈øtein, in that part thereof, which belongs to the King of Denmarke. And, as for this Dukes two Regiments, they are disbanded; part of them being taken on by the Swedes, & part into the King of Denmarks ≈øervice, and the≈øe la≈øt ≈øent away for Gluck≈øtadt. As I gue≈ø≈øed by my la≈øt, ≈øo is it already fallen out with Kremper Mar≈øh, Wil≈øter Mar≈øh, and Ditmar≈øh: for all the≈øe lower Lands neere the Elve, and We≈øt Sea, this fro≈øty weather are fallen into the hands of the Swedes Armie: 150. of the Pay≈øans, with
≈øome Souldiers being there ≈ølaine, and 300. more taken pri≈øoners, that made re≈øi≈øtance; and all the≈øe places will doubtle≈ø≈øe fare the wor≈øe, becau≈øe they refu≈øed Torten≈øon entrance, when he fir≈øt required it both by me≈ø≈øage and writing. Ye≈øterday, by an expre≈ø≈øe, I received a letter my ≈øelf from Colonell Dowglas (who as Major Generall commands the left wing of the Swedes Armie) in the≈øe words, Viz. The ninth of this moneth we have begun our wars very fortunatly here in Juitland; in re≈øpect we did encounter the whole Cavalerie of the Danes in the≈øe parts; who were twelve hundred hor≈øe ≈øtrong, of the be≈øt mounted manly-like-men, that ever I did ≈øee, a mile on this ≈øide Colding; and beate them ≈øo, as that there did not 200. come into their Leaguer, the mo≈øt part of their Officers killed, and their Principalls taken pri≈øoners, as Lievtenant Colonell Bockwald (who commanded them) Ritmei≈øter Ulfild, Ritmei≈øter Luke, and divers other Ritmei≈øters, Lieutenants and under Officers: we are now lying here in the Dorpes about the King of Denmarks Foot, which lyes in a retrenched Leaguer on this ≈øide of the Belt, over again≈øt Middleford in Funen; they are e≈øteemed 7 or 8 thou≈øand ≈øtrong, but more then the half part mi≈øerable poore Bawres; we are about an exploit, which if it effectuate will make us a good warre. Thus far he. Now this day here is fre≈øh newes come, that the Swedes with their Ordnance, were ≈øince advanced before this Leaguer; and that after they had Canoncerd upon it a while, and that the Danes ≈øaw them ready to make a faire a≈ø≈øault upon them, they threw down their Armes, and cryed out for Quarter; the Mar≈øhall of Denmarke Andreas Bilke (who Commanded in chiefe) ≈øeeing them≈øelves too weake to oppo≈øe the Swedes, tooke away their Colours, Ordnance, chief Officers, and as many of the be≈øt common Souldiers, as ≈øo ≈øhort time would give
him leave; and e≈øcaped therewith by ≈ømall ≈øhipping into Funen; yet left behinde them ≈øundry Captaines and under Officers, be≈øides all their Hor≈øes, and foure thou≈øand five hundred Foot men, whereof one thou≈øand old Souldiers, and therewith many of the Bawres or Pay≈øons al≈øo willingly ranged them≈øelves among≈øt the Swedes Troupes; the re≈øt, after the Souldiers had ≈øtripped them of their be≈øt cloths, were ≈øent away unto their homes: This is the effect of a Letter ≈øent unto this Town, which was written by Torten≈øon him≈øelf; who added hereunto, that by this generall defeate of the Dani≈øh Forces both Hor≈øe and Foot, he accounted the whole Continent on this ≈øide the Belt, to be as good as in their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; and this letter of his I my ≈øelf have ≈øeen, bearing date at Middleford Skonce the 14. of this moneth. What the King of Denmark doth in Zealand, Funen, or Schonen, we know not, more then in generall, that he maketh all the preparation for the wars that he can: for all the Pa≈ø≈øages out of Denmark are ≈øtopped, ≈øo that we can have no certaine Intelligence from thence as yet. It hath been rumoured here abroad al this week that the States of Denmark, and Sweden, were treating together upon the borders of both Kingdomes; and ≈øuch adverti≈øement was brought al≈øo unto the Chancellour of Denmark (who is yet here) as I had it from him≈øelf. But Lowis de Geere (a man of good account, and at this time employed from the Crown of Sweden for Holland) arrived here ye≈øterday, affirming that him≈øelf came by ≈øhipping from Calmar (being not far off the borders) the 12. of this moneth, and that then there was neither any ≈øuch meeting, nor yet any ≈øpeech thereof; but that Fieldmar≈øhall Gu≈øtavius Horn had 20. thou≈øand men on Foote, and was with them to march into Denmark the 20. of this moneth. The Chancellour afore≈øaid faith, the King of Denmark hath in Schonen already
13. or 14. thou≈øand men to make head again≈øt the Swedes there; and that 18 thou≈øand more are ≈øhortly to come out of Norwegen, but the≈øe being (for the mo≈øt part) Pay≈øans, not injured to the wars; it is to be feared that they will not be able to with≈øtand the fierce irruptions of the Swedes Armies; e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the≈øe la≈øt have had already ≈øuch ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in their enterpri≈øes on this ≈øide the Belt. The Chancellour al≈øo let me under≈øtand that the King his Ma≈øter, hath lately ≈øent unto him, and the re≈øt of his Colleagues at O≈ønabrugge, his Letters of revocation; requiring them to come away from thence with all expedition. So what will become of the generall Treaties when they are departed, we ≈øhall ≈øee ere long, at lea≈øt whither they will goe forward or not. We have nothing this weeke of the Imperiall Army above in High Germanie; ≈øave onely that they have betaken them≈øelves into their Winter Quarters. And this being what this week affords, I humbly take leave, and remaine ever

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips most humble and mo≈øt faithfull Servant, J. Avery.

div.head: To the Right Honourable, Sr. Thomas Rowe, Knight, Chancelour of the most Noble Order of the Garter, and one of the Lords of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt honourable Privie Councel, &c.
div.p:
I Am told this day, that Fieldmar≈øhall Torten≈øon hath given the Lord≈øhip of Wandesbeck (belonging to Count Pentz, and ≈øcituate within two Engli≈øh miles of this town) unto one whom the Officers call here, The Swedes Agent; and that hee hath already taken po≈ø≈øe≈øsion thereof, this ≈øeeming to argue what minde the Swedes beare, when they thus begin to di≈øpo≈øe of places in Hol≈øtein as of a conquered Countrey. From Dan≈øick the Hollands Re≈øident writes of newes to be arrived there, out of Moravia, that the Emperours towns in Hungaria have declared Ragotzy for an Enemy, that he hath an Army on foot of above 30. thou≈øand men; and that the Turke will joyn unto them 24000. more to make war again≈øt the Emperour; ≈øure it is, that he hath received monies from the crown of Sweden, and France both; and this makes many to conjecture, that the Emperour
will have work enough for his Armies above in the Countrey; and that the Swedes will have no di≈øturbance from thence unto their proceedings in the≈øe parts: others conceive that the Crown of Sweden have a purpo≈øe to make a particular peace with the Emperour, that they may the better intend and pur≈øue their new begun warre again≈øt the King of Denmark; and it is written from Leip≈øick, that they have a conference about this time with the Imperiali≈øts at Fridburg in Lu≈øatia, about a truce, a little more time will give us more light to judge of the weight of the≈øe conjectures; but in the mean time, the Landgravin of He≈ø≈øen, hath ≈øent a principall Mini≈øter of Hers to expo≈øtulate with Torten≈øon, for drawing away all his forces ≈øo far off from a≈øsi≈øting of Hers, and for beginning of this new war to ≈øtirr up more enemies again≈øt them≈øelves and their Allyes. This being what this week affords, I humbly ki≈ø≈øe your hands, and remain

closer.signed: Your Honours mo≈øt humble and mo≈øt faithfull Servant, I. AVERY.
